title: Lakers give huge update on Austin Reaves before Tuesday's game vs Suns
description: Will Austin Reaves be able to play on Tuesday for the Lakers when they visit the Suns?
fullText:
The Los Angeles Lakers have been dealing with injuries to key players lately. Austin Reaves, Deandre Ayton, Rui Hachimura and Luka Doncic have all suffered ailments over the last week or two, and it is one reason the team has won just four of its last eight games.

When Los Angeles takes on the Phoenix Suns on Tuesday to wrap up a four-game road trip, it will still be without Doncic and Hachimura. Ayton will return to action after missing two games due to elbow soreness.

Reaves was originally listed as questionable for Tuesday's game. But he will play versus Phoenix, which will give L.A. a big boost.

Austin Reaves has been upgraded to available for tonight against PHX, the Lakers announced. He will return after a three game absence because of a mild left calf strain.

‚Äî Dave McMenamin (@mcten) December 23, 2025

Reaves is averaging 27.8 points and 6.7 assists a game while shooting 50.3% from the field and 36.9% from 3-point range so far this season. In 21 games, he has hit the 40-point mark three times already, and he had a new career high of 51 points on Oct. 26 versus the Sacramento Kings.

He has a history of putting up big scoring numbers whenever either Doncic or LeBron James has been out, and that is exactly what it will likely take for the Lakers to defeat a potent and feisty Suns squad.

This article originally appeared on LeBron Wire: Lakers give huge update on Austin Reaves before Tuesday's game vs Suns

title: Lakers' Bronny James faced a former All-Star and had one of his best games of the season
description: LeBron's son is continuing to work on his game.
fullText:
Lakers' Bronny James faced a former All-Star and had one of his best games of the season originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Bronny James is seeing some action in the G League as LeBron's son continues to work on his development.

On Sunday, Bronny got to match up with a former NBA All-Star, and he played very well.

The matchup for Bronny with the South Bay Lakers was against the Wisconsin Herd, who feature Victor Oladipo.

Oladipo, another athletically gifted guard, is past his prime and was never quite the same after multiple major injuries, but he's still got an impressive basketball pedigree.

Bronny finished the night with:

MORE:¬†Nikola Jokic just broke an NBA record that might end up being unbreakable

You can check out the highlights in this post from X:

Bronny James vs. Victor Oladipo in the G-League tonight:

15 points
5 assists
3 rebounds
6/13 FG
+6 +/-
34 minutes

(via @SLAMonline) pic.twitter.com/pphnJ09EKS

‚Äî Legion Hoops (@LegionHoops) December 22, 2025

Maybe the most impressive and encouraging part of those highlights is Bronny's jump shooting.

He's regarded as a solid defender and athlete, but his handle and shot have both been in question, and at his size, he needs to have at least one of those to make it in the NBA.

Multiple 3-pointers in rhythm show that Bronny is starting to develop that part of his game.

Skeptics will continue to doubt Bronny, especially while he spends time in the G League, but it may indeed be the best path for him to make the necessary improvements to last in the NBA.

title: JJ Redick gives updates on Rui Hachimura, Austin Reaves, Deandre Ayton
description: The Lakers are very short-handed right now, and they need to get healthier, as they have two big matchups in the coming days.
fullText:
Over the last few days, the Los Angeles Lakers have suddenly become very short-handed. First, they lost Austin Reaves to a calf strain he suffered just over a week ago, and then starting center Deandre Ayton came down with elbow soreness and missed their last two games.

Then, against the Los Angeles Clippers on Saturday, they didn't have starting forward Rui Hachimura, who is dealing with a groin ailment. To make matters worse, Luka Doncic sustained a leg contusion during that game and was ruled out for the second half. Without so many key players, the Lakers had a huge lack of offensive firepower and lost 103-88 to the Clippers.

Head coach JJ Redick said that he hopes Hachimura will be back after missing a total of only a few days.

JJ Redick says Rui Hachimura, out tonight with a sore groin, started to feel discomfort in his hip in the UTA game. Redick says ‚Äúthe hope‚Äù is Hachimura is only out for 3-5 days

‚Äî Dave McMenamin (@mcten) December 21, 2025

He also added that Ayton and Reaves are improving, although he didn't say whether either of them will play in the team's next game on Tuesday versus the Phoenix Suns.

Redick added that Deandre Ayton (left elbow) and Austin Reaves (left calf) are both progressing and did not rule out either of them playing in PHX on Tuesday https://t.co/GeFicCsrlL

‚Äî Dave McMenamin (@mcten) December 21, 2025

The Lakers have a marquee matchup coming up on Christmas Day versus Kevin Durant and the Houston Rockets, who are 17-8 and right behind the Lakers in fifth place in the Western Conference. Five days later, the Purple and Gold will host the Detroit Pistons, who have the Eastern Conference's best record at 22-6.

Needless to say, they will need to be somewhere close to full strength in order to defeat either team, let alone both of them.

This article originally appeared on LeBron Wire: JJ Redick gives updates on Rui Hachimura, Austin Reaves, Deandre Ayton

title: Jake LaRavia opens up about his shooting struggles
description: LaRavia hasn't been as efficient as the Lakers have hoped this season.
fullText:
Jake LaRavia opens up about his shooting struggles originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The Los Angeles Lakers have struggled from three-point range this season, shooting 34.3%, 25th in the NBA.

In a 15-point loss last night against the Clippers, the Lakers shot an abysmal 16% from three (6-for-38). With Rui Hachimura and Deandre Ayton sidelined, Jake LaRavia entered the starting lineup.

Although the fourth-year forward posted a double-double with 12 points, 11 rebounds and six assists, he continues to struggle from beyond the arc.

LaRavia shot 0-for-4 from deep in what has been an inefficient shooting season. His 30.5% from deep is a career-low, after averaging a career-high 42.3% from beyond the arc last season.

Following the game, LaRavia spoke on his shooting struggles, expecting to get back on track soon. ¬†‚ÄúI know I‚Äôm a good shooter, everyone on the staff knows I‚Äôm a good shooter, everyone on the team knows I‚Äôm a good shooter,‚Äù LaRavia said. ‚ÄúAt some point, I have to make shots. Obviously, been in a slump pretty much this entire season outside of that first stretch of games where I was making some. But they‚Äôll drop.‚Äù

For Los Angeles, they'll need LaRavia to step up, especially if Luka Doncic is sidelined for an extended period. Even when Los Angeles is fully healthy, 34.3% from deep isn't a recipe for success in the modern NBA.

In addition to LaRavia, role players like Marcus Smart, Gabe Vincent and Dalton Knecht will be relied upon to knock down threes in support of Doncic, LeBron James and Austin Reaves.

The Lakers will return to action Tuesday against the Phoenix Suns.

title: Luka Doncic leaves Lakers loss at half with left leg contusion
description: The Clippers also lost Ivica Zubac during the game to an ankle injury
fullText:
Luka Doncic left the Lakers' loss to the Clippers Saturday at halftime and did not return with what the team is calling a left leg contusion.

Doncic left the building without talking to reporters, and coach J.J. Redick's postgame comments didn't shed much light on the situation (quote via Dave McMenamin of ESPN).

"I saw him hobbling towards the end of the first half. He came to me at halftime and said he couldn't go‚Ä¶ I don't have any other information."

The injury clearly bothered him for much of the game. Doncic, the NBA's leading scorer at 35.2 points per game, scored just 12 points on the night shooting 4-of-13 (1-of-6 from 3-point range).

Doncic wasn't the only significant injury in this game. Clippers center Ivica Zubac went to the ground in the first quarter and instantly limped back to the locker room with what was described as an ankle injury. He did not return to the game and the Clippers said he would be re-evaluated on Sunday. Zubac has been one of the few consistent bright spots in the Clippers' season, averaging 15.6 points and 11.1 rebounds per game.

The Clippers picked up their first home win since Halloween with the 103-88 victory over the Lakers. Kawhi Leonard led the Clippers with 32 points and 12 rebounds, while James Harden pitched in with 21 points and 10 assists.

LeBron James led the Lakers with 36 points, but every other Laker combined to shoot 31.7% on the night, including 3-of-30 from beyond the arc.

title: NBA Insider says Lakers interested in Pelicans' Herb Jones
description: The veteran wing could solidify the Lakers' rotation.
fullText:
NBA Insider says Lakers interested in Pelicans' Herb Jones originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Trade talks surrounding the Los Angeles Lakers are heating up, and the Lakers appear to be in pursuit of a veteran forward.

According to Michael Scotto of HoopsHype, the Lakers are pursuing New Orleans Pelicans wing Herb Jones.

‚ÄúThe Los Angeles Lakers are monitoring the trade market for a defensive wing upgrade, league sources told HoopsHype.¬†Among the 3-and-D wing upgrades on their wish list is New Orleans Pelicans forward¬†Herb Jones, league sources say.‚Äù

Jones is widely considered one of the NBA‚Äôs top defenders. He‚Äôs averaged 1.6 steals and 0.7 blocks during his five NBA seasons. He would give the Lakers an aggressive defender who can match up with guards at the point of attack.

Jones has been a key member of the Pelicans‚Äô rotation since his rookie year in 2021. He‚Äôs averaging 10.1 points, 3.8 rebounds, 2.3 assists and shooting 40.3% from the field this season. He‚Äôs also been a reliable 3-point shooter, shooting 33.7% this season and 36.2% for his career.

He only played 20 games last season due to a posterior labrum tear in his right shoulder. He‚Äôs already matched that total this season but missed around a week in November with a calf strain.

Jones is set to make $13.9 million this season and signed a three-year, $67.58M extension with the Pelicans last summer. The Lakers have limited future draft picks and cap space. Their 2031 unprotected first round pick could be enticing to the Pelicans, who could look to retool their roster around their rookies.

title: NBA insider confirms Lakers continue to monitor Giannis Antetokounmpo, looking to pair star with Luka Doncic
description: Would a Doncic-Antetokounmpo pairing rival Shaq & Kobe?
fullText:
NBA insider confirms Lakers continue to monitor Giannis Antetokounmpo, looking to pair star with Luka Doncic originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Whenever star players become available in the NBA, or even when they‚Äôre simply involved in rumors, the Los Angeles Lakers are typically linked to them.

Whether it‚Äôs to drive up the price or because the Lakers have a genuine interest, we see it happen all the time.

It‚Äôs a bit crazy how often the Lakers are connected to these names, but nobody would have expected the team to trade for Luka Doncic a year ago.

Perhaps Lakers fans have a point when they believe the franchise will eventually land another star.

The latest name to surface is Giannis Antetokounmpo of the Milwaukee Bucks. While the Bucks may not be looking to move on from Antetokounmpo, Michael Scotto of HoopsHype reported that teams like the Lakers continue to monitor the situation, even if nothing is pressing at the moment.

‚ÄúIn fact, rival executives interested in trading for Antetokounmpo who‚Äôve spoken with HoopsHype said they don‚Äôt believe Milwaukee wants to move him right now. With that said, it‚Äôs unlikely to keep teams such as the New York Knicks, Miami Heat, Golden State Warriors, Los Angeles Lakers, San Antonio Spurs, Atlanta Hawks, Minnesota Timberwolves, Houston Rockets, and others from continuing to monitor Antetokounmpo‚Äôs situation to varying degrees, looking ahead,‚Äù he wrote.

Landing Antetokounmpo would give the Lakers one of the best duos in the NBA for a long time, assuming he and Doncic can stay on the court when it matters most.

Antetokounmpo has dealt with his fair share of injuries, but he would still be worth whatever the Lakers would have to give up.

title: Lakers face Luka Doncic-LeBron James crossroads after JJ Redick's latest on-court experiment
description: The Los Angeles Lakers are trying to ask Luka Doncic something that is completely not what he is used to.
fullText:
Lakers face Luka Doncic-LeBron James crossroads after JJ Redick's latest on-court experiment originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The Los Angeles Lakers pulled off one of the most groundbreaking trades just before the deadline last February. Acquiring Luka Donƒçiƒá was one of the most shocking deals in NBA history. While the Lakers want to build around him‚Äîand understand that it may take time‚ÄîDonƒçiƒá still wants to win now.

‚ÄúDonƒçiƒá being just 26 gives the Lakers a far longer timeline to build a championship-contending team, but that doesn't mean they can slow down and take their time. Donƒçiƒá told Lakers president Rob Pelinka and coach JJ Redick in May that he's not interested in taking the slow approach in building a contender,‚Äù CBS Sports‚Äô Jasmyn Wimbish wrote.

Los Angeles got off to a hot start, but lately the team has become stagnant. Defense has been a major reason for that struggle. As a result, head coach JJ Redick reportedly called a meeting with Donƒçiƒá and LeBron James, challenging them to step up on that end of the floor.

‚ÄúIt was good. We talked about a lot - not just that. But he was right. You got to get a little bit more, especially from the star players. So that‚Äôs on us, that‚Äôs on me.‚Äù - Luka Donƒçiƒá on JJ Redick‚Äôs recent meeting where he asked for more on the defensive end from him and LeBron,‚Äù Lakers insider Dave McMenamin posted.

It also appears that Redick is working to get Donƒçiƒá more involved off the ball.

‚ÄúJJ just inferred that he's been trying to get Luka to play more off-ball, but he's been reluctant and uncomfortable. However he made some progress in that regard today. If Luka learns how to play off-ball, even a 10% increase would make the Lakers so much more dangerous,‚Äù Lakers Daily posted.

While getting Donƒçiƒá involved off the ball could benefit the offense, it may also signal that Redick is still searching for the best way to keep all of his stars engaged. LeBron James has yet to have a truly dominant game, and that could be due in part to not having the ball in his hands as often.

Redick now appears to be at a crossroads as he works to maximize his roster. This is his current solution, but if Donƒçiƒá is unwilling to fully embrace the change, the offense could suffer. If these issues aren‚Äôt addressed soon, they could quickly become a significant problem.

title: Lakers want Luka Doncic, LeBron James to engage more on defense
description: Jarred Vanderbilt sparked the Lakers' defensive effort in the win over Phoenix on Sunday, but they'll need their stars to contribute as well against Utah.
fullText:
They saw how ‚Äúcontagious‚Äù it was when playing defense at a high level against the Suns and how Jarred Vanderbilt lit the fuse to ignite things for the Lakers in their last victory over Phoenix.

And for the Lakers to maintain that defensive mindset, stars Luka Doncic and LeBron James also have to be committed to that end of the court.

That was the message from Lakers coach JJ Redick to Doncic and James.

"Yeah, it was good," Doncic said. "We talked about a lot, not just that, but he was right. You got to get a little big more, especially from the star players. So that's on us. That's on me. And we just got to give more, especially at the start of the game. We got to start the game better. But I think in Phoenix, we did a pretty good job. The plan was focused on ourselves and [our] defensive mentality, so I think we did a pretty good job."

The Lakers will be tested again on defense by the Utah Jazz Thursday night in Salt Lake City.

The Jazz have a developing star in Lauri Markkanen, a difficult matchup at 7-foot-1 who is ninth in the NBA in scoring at 27.8 points per game, and a young talent in guard Keyonte George, who is averaging 23.5 points and 6.8 assists.

Utah is fourth in the league in pace (102.98), ninth in scoring (119.0), second in assists (29.8). The Jazz are fifth in rebounds (45.7), eighth in offensive rebounds (12.6), and 12th in field-goal percentage.

"The way we play, we got to approach every game the same," Doncic said. "In the NBA, every team is dangerous, so at some point somebody can go for 40. They have Markkanen, and then George. They can go for 40 on any night. So we just got to work on ourselves and approach the game, make everything the same."

The all-out energy and effort by Vanderbilt off the bench was the catalyst for the Lakers against the Suns.

In his 15 minutes of action, he had seven ponits, seven rebounds, two steals and one blocked shot.

Vanderbilt had played only three minutes and eight seconds over a 10-game stretch prior to that point.

‚ÄúVando's minutes were huge,‚Äù Gabe Vincent said. ‚ÄúHe came in and does what we all know he's very capable of doing and being disruptive on the defensive end, crashing the glass, getting extra possessions for us, all of which we desperately needed. You know what I mean? So his spark off the bench was huge for us."

Now it‚Äôs about sustaining that defensive intensity, the Lakers say. And about playing with that physicality, the Lakers say.

‚ÄúYeah, when you guys asked me this the last time, it‚Äôs effort,‚Äù Jake LaRavia said. ‚ÄúIf we just go out there and we give that kind of effort every night‚Ä¶We got a lot of guys on the team. Some guys might not be having it and, like you said about that contagious word, that really helps out. (Marcus) Smart does it sometimes. Vando does it sometimes. I would say I do it just being a contagious type of person to help lead the team and just being extra physical.‚Äù

The Lakers are ranked near the bottom of the league in some defensive categories, which means there remains room for improvement.

They are ranked 17th in the league in points allowed (116.7), 24th in field-goal percentage (48.1%) allowed and 28th in three-point shooting (38.1%) allowed.

‚ÄúYou just got to go out there and do it,‚Äù LaRavia said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not anything a coach can say. It‚Äôs not anything a player can tell another player. Yeah, it‚Äôs like the individual player‚Äôs job to go out there and give effort on defense and that‚Äôs contagious. It just goes around.‚Äù

Lakers center Deandre Ayton on Wednesday was named by the NBA and the National Basketball Players Assn. as the winner of the Bob Lanier Community Assist Award for November. Ayton was recognized for his philanthropic work across the Bahamas, which is his home country, Jamaica and Los Angeles through the Ayton Family Foundation.

This story originally appeared in Los Angeles Times.

title: What did Bronny James say? Lakers fans duped by viral fake post about LeBron's son
description: The Lakers' second-year guard is doing his best.
fullText:
What did Bronny James say? Lakers fans duped by viral fake post about LeBron's son originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Bronny James is trying to make it in the NBA.

The Los Angeles Lakers' second-year guard is doing it as the son of the legendary LeBron James. Those are big footsteps to follow.

Because of his name, and his lineage, Bronny has immense attention on him at all times. Every move is dissected, every decision analyzed.

It also creates opportunities for others to capitalize on Bronny's name, which is what happened in a new viral post that isn't real.

To be clear: Bronny didn't say anything bad about his NBA career.

This fake viral post suggests that he did in an Instagram comment:

This Bronny interaction with a fan.. üò≥ pic.twitter.com/RGGXHMyGPl

‚Äî NBACentel (@TheNBACentel) December 16, 2025

That comes from the account NBA Centel, which is a popular parody account.

Bronny has put his head down and done his work. He's given no indication that he wants to be anything less than the best player he can be.

It's unfortunate that he has to deal with this kind of stuff.

title: Paul Pierce on Lakers' basketball IQ in crunch time of Sunday's game
description: Former NBA star Paul Pierce didn't hold back when he described the Lakers' poor decision-making in the final minutes of Sunday's win over the Suns.
fullText:
Late in the third quarter of their Sunday matchup against the Phoenix Suns, the Los Angeles Lakers started to play the type of winning defense that their fans have been practically begging for. During a stretch of roughly 10 minutes that extended into the fourth quarter, they scored 24 unanswered points and forced seven turnovers, allowing them to take a 95-77 lead.

However, after that outstanding spurt, the Lakers fell back into their old bad habits on both ends of the floor. They started to walk the ball upcourt and milk the shot clock, as if they were merely looking to conservatively protect their lead rather than build on it and hold off Phoenix. That behavior played right into Phoenix's hands, and they ended up having to pull out a 116-114 victory by the skin of their teeth after the Suns made a couple of big mistakes in the final seconds.

It was another reminder that the Lakers still have a lot of work to do in order to seriously contend for the NBA championship.

Hall of Famer Paul Pierce went off on them during a recent episode of the "No Fouls Given" podcast for the way they gave up their lead in the last several minutes of Sunday's game. He said the Lakers ‚Äî and the Suns ‚Äî had very poor basketball IQ in the final minutes of that contest, and that neither team will be able to win a playoff series this spring as a result.

"This was one of the lowest IQ, last four minutes I've seen from both teams this season. And based on what I saw, neither one of these teams can win a playoff series."

Of course, the Lakers are likely not as reckless and undisciplined as they looked in the final minutes of Sunday's game, nor are they as good a defensive team as they looked during that 10-minute stretch late in the third quarter and early in the fourth quarter. They do have an 18-7 record, which gives them an elite winning percentage, and are in third place in the Western Conference.

But Los Angeles hasn't played the Denver Nuggets, Houston Rockets or New York Knicks yet, and when it faced the defending NBA champion Oklahoma City Thunder a month ago, it lost 121-92, albeit with LeBron James still out due to sciatica. Continuing to put forth the same ineptitude they displayed late in Sunday's game will almost certainly result in decisive losses against the Nuggets, Rockets, Knicks and especially the Thunder.

This article originally appeared on LeBron Wire: Paul Pierce on Lakers' basketball IQ in crunch time of Sunday's game

title: JJ Redick confused by LeBron James usurping clear Luka Doncic duty for Lakers
description: This was a curious moment to be sure.
fullText:
JJ Redick confused by LeBron James usurping clear Luka Doncic duty for Lakers originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

LeBron James took, and missed, two technical foul shots on Sunday for the Los Angeles Lakers.

His head coach, JJ Redick, was confused afterward about why LeBron took the second one (which came after Dillon Brooks chest-bumped the King).

"Luka should have taken that," Redick told reporters after the game.

As you probably know, any player on the floor at the time of the technical foul can take the ensuing free throw.

It really doesn't make sense for LeBron to be taking any of those over Doncic.

In his career, James is a 73% foul shooter. Doncic is at 75%.

This season, it's more glaring. LeBron has made just 61.9% of his free throws. Doncic is at 81.1%.

The numbers all align on the same side: Doncic should take the techs, not James.

Sure, there's likely an urge to be the guy to take the foul shot yourself if you're the one who essentially draws the technical foul.

But in a close game, it makes more sense to have the guy who is¬†more likely to make the foul shot¬†take the foul shot.

For the Lakers, that's Luka and not LeBron.

Going forward, it's safe to expect L.A. to get this right. Points are too valuable to be lowering the odds.

MORE:¬†'Blocked by James' call makes unexpected return during Lakers game

title: James and Brooks clash in Lakers win over Phoenix
description: LeBron James scores 26 points and clashes with Dillon Brooks as the Los Angeles Lakers beat the Phoenix Suns 116-114 on Sunday.
fullText:
LeBron James scored 26 points and clashed with Dillon Brooks as the Los Angeles Lakers beat the Phoenix Suns 116-114 on Sunday.

The Lakers were 20 points ahead in the fourth quarter when the Suns fought back to take a one-point lead with 12 seconds remaining after a three-pointer by Brooks.

In a frantic end to the game in Phoenix, Brooks then bumped James, drawing his second technical foul of the night and an ejection.

James, 40, missed the technical free throw but was then fouled by Suns' Devin Booker on a three-point attempt and made two of three free throws with three seconds left to put the Lakers back ahead.

"It's the NBA, no boys allowed," James said of his tangle with Brooks, 29.

title: Lakers jersey history No. 18 ‚Äî Chariton Arnold Ferrin Jr.
description: A look at Chariton Arnold Ferrin Jr.'s time with the Lakers.
fullText:
Through the 2024-25 season, the Los Angeles Lakers have had a total of 506 players suit up for them, going back to their days in Minneapolis. Some were forgettable, some were serviceable, some were good and a select few were flat-out legendary.

During the Lakers' 80th season of existence (they were founded back in 1946 as the Detroit Gems in the National Basketball League), LeBron Wire is taking a look at each player who has worn their jersey, whether it has been a purple and gold one or the ones they donned back in the Midwest during their early years.

Chariton Arnold Ferrin Jr. was a basketball star in college while at the University of Utah. In 1944, he was named the Most Outstanding Player of the NCAA Tournament as the Utes won the national championship, and three years later, he helped the school win a National Invitation Tournament title.

The Lakers took Ferrin in the third round of the 1948 draft, and he spent three seasons in the NBA, with all of them coming as a member of the Lakers. He averaged 5.8 points and 1.6 assists a game during that time and won championships during both of his first two seasons in the league.

After his NBA career ended, Ferrin had a short stint as the general manager of the American Basketball Association's Utah Stars in the 1970s, and afterward, he was the athletic director for the Utes from 1976 to 1985. During his time as athletic director, the Utes won a total of 10 national championships, including four NCAA titles in women's gymnastics.

This article originally appeared on LeBron Wire: Lakers jersey history No. 18 ‚Äî Chariton Arnold Ferrin Jr.

title: Is LeBron James playing vs. Suns tonight? Final status for Lakers star
description: Less than two weeks after their first meeting of the season, the Los Angeles Lakers and Phoenix Suns are set to go head-to-head on Sunday night.  The Suns won the first meeting between the two teams by a score of 125-108, so the Lakers will be looking for some revenge this time around.  LeBron James, who has been dealing with various ailments throughout the season, isn‚Äôt listed on the official injury report for the contest, so he should be good to go.
fullText:
Is LeBron James playing vs. Suns tonight? Final status for Lakers star originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Less than two weeks after their first meeting of the season, the Los Angeles Lakers and Phoenix Suns are set to go head-to-head again on Sunday night.

The Suns won the first meeting between the two teams by a score of 125-108, so the Lakers will be looking for some revenge this time around. Luckily, they‚Äôll have their future Hall-of-Famer available for the game.

LeBron James, who has been dealing with various ailments throughout the season, isn‚Äôt listed on the official injury report for the contest, so he should be good to go.¬†On the season, James is averaging 16.5 points, 7.6 assists and 6.0 rebounds per performance in just eight appearances.

But, while James will be available for L.A. against Phoenix, a few other players won‚Äôt be. Austin Reaves, Maxi Kleber and Bronny James have all been ruled out of the game. Reaves, who has been a huge factor in L.A.'s early-season success, is expected to miss a week of action with a calf strain.

Meanwhile, the Suns will be without Jalen Green and Isaiah Livers. Star guard Devin Booker is also listed as questionable for the contest.

Heading into the game, the Lakers are fifth in the Western Conference standings with a 17-7 record while the Suns sit seventh at 14-11. Since they're in the same division, the two teams will play two more times this season after Sunday, including once later this month. They'll also play in late February.

title: Lakers predicted to cut ties with Luka Doncic's former $33 million Mavericks teammate
description: A Los Angeles Lakers writer believes the franchise should consider moving on from a nine-year veteran.
fullText:
Lakers predicted to cut ties with Luka Doncic's former $33 million Mavericks teammate originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

It‚Äôs safe to say the Los Angeles Lakers will look a bit different by the time the Feb. 5 trade deadline passes.

The franchise has plenty of tradable assets it can use in a midseason deal to upgrade its roster. Lake Show Life‚Äôs Svyatoslav Rovenchuk is under the impression that Luka Doncic‚Äôs 6-foot-10 former Dallas Mavericks teammate is among the assets the Lakers will move on from this season.

‚ÄúThe Golden State Warriors proved last season why it can be advantageous to make a move early,‚Äù Rovenchuk wrote Friday. ‚ÄúThey acquired Dennis Schroder, gave the experiment a shot, and rerouted him in favor of eventually securing Jimmy Butler when the initial venture failed.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf the Lakers were going to replicate a similar approach, there is one clear member of the roster who stands out as a part of the outgoing package for Los Angeles. That would be Maxi Kleber.‚Äù

‚ÄúKleber has been sidelined recently, dealing with a lower back injury. With the Lakers struggling to find defense, athleticism, shooting, and bench scoring, any one of these needs could have him moved before even being given the opportunity to return to the court for Los Angeles.‚Äù

While it may not be easy to believe, Kleber was once a valuable stretch four who played respectable pick-and-pop basketball alongside Doncic in Los Angeles.

Fast forward to the 2025-26 season, and Kleber, who was included in the blockbuster Feb. 2 trade that landed Doncic with the Lakers, is a low-impact contributor for JJ Redick‚Äôs crew.

While Kleber is shooting 37.5% from three, he‚Äôs contributing just 1.8 points and 1.8 rebounds per game in 12.1 minutes, signaling that it may be time to part ways with the 33-year-old big man.

If one thing‚Äôs certain, Kleber is running out of time to prove himself in Los Angeles.

More NBA:¬†Spurs' Stephon Castle makes basketball history never done ever before in NBA

title: TST Today: Clippers Chaos, Lakers Cup Crash & USC‚Äôs SoFi Twist
description: Welcome to The Sporting Tribune Podcast Network and a new episode of The Sporting Tribune Today, our every-weekday show on sports in Southern California, Las Vegas and Hawaii.
fullText:
Welcome to The Sporting Tribune Podcast Network and a new episode of The Sporting Tribune Today, our every-weekday show on sports in Southern California, Las Vegas and Hawaii. Hosted by Arash Markazi, Grant Mona, and Anwar Stetson, with guest Josh Tariff, today‚Äôs episode dives into a packed and chaotic week in L.A. sports.

The Sporting Tribune Today LIVE: Clippers Woes Continue, Lakers Fall in NBA Cup, Rams-Lions Preview, USC at SoFi??? https://t.co/zEHawcqbIg

‚Äî The Sporting Tribune (@SportingTrib) December 12, 2025

Segment One ‚Äî Clippers Meltdown & Ty Lue Silent: The crew opens with the Clippers‚Äô disastrous start to the season, breaking down what‚Äôs gone wrong on both ends of the floor, why panic is already spreading among fans, and the growing pressure around the roster. They also discuss Ty Lue‚Äôs decision not to speak to the media, what that signals internally, and how the organization is handling the unraveling.

Segment Two ‚Äî Lakers‚Äô NBA Cup Exit & USC at SoFi?In the second segment, the hosts react to the Lakers‚Äô loss in the NBA Cup, what the defeat revealed about the team‚Äôs flaws, and what adjustments are needed moving forward. They close by discussing the developing story of USC potentially playing at SoFi Stadium, what‚Äôs driving the idea, and how it could reshape the Trojans‚Äô future.

The podcast can be heard every day on Apple, Google, Spotify, iHeart Radio, TuneIn and wherever you get your podcast and every weekday on the radio on KIRN 670 AM and 95.5 FMHD3 in Southern California, 98.5 The Bet in Las Vegas and the Hawaii Sports Radio Network 95.1 FM and 760 AM in Hawaii.

title: Warriors, Lakers are circling the Pelicans for key trade targets
description: New Orleans could be key to this season.
fullText:
Warriors, Lakers are circling the Pelicans for key trade targets originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The New Orleans Pelicans are having one of the worst seasons in the NBA.

They could also be crucial to how the rest of the year plays out in the Western Conference.

That's because the Pels have two trade chips that are sought after by a lot of the league: Trey Murphy III and Herbert Jones.

The latest reporting from The Athletic's Sam Amick indicates that the Golden State Warriors are especially intrigued by Murphy, and that the Los Angeles Lakers really want Jones.

"For quite some time now, the Warriors have been open about their desire to acquire the Pelicans‚Äô Trey Murphy III," Amick writes. "But if they‚Äôre going to use Kuminga to do that, then it would be helpful to know how, if at all, the Pelicans value the Warriors‚Äô 23-year-old forward. For the time being, the feedback is mixed on that front. ‚ÄôTis the season for smokescreens, after all."

MORE:¬†This Warriors news leak about a Draymond-Giannis trade is hilarious

Murphy could be a part of the Pelicans' core alongside Derik Queen, if they want to go that route. It remains to be seen what they'll do with him.

Jones would cost a bit less in a trade, at least in concept.

"Our Lakers‚Äô beat writer, Dan Woike,¬†highlighted their interest¬†in Jones this week," Amick writes. "At the same time, he cited team and league sources who said the Pelicans are 'not interested' in moving Jones. Fair enough, but let‚Äôs circle back for a vibe check in late January."

New Orleans is already struggling. If the struggles only get worse, the Pelicans will have little choice but to consider trades to try to prop up their future, since their present doesn't appear to be going anywhere.

The Warriors and Lakers will be circling for that moment of opportunity to come.

Why it's time for the Pelicans to move on from Zion

The Bucks have a looming $275 million Giannis problem

Timberwolves want Coby White, but there's a catch

title: Lakers jersey history No. 17 ‚Äî Jeremy Lin
description: A look at Jeremy Lin's time with the Lakers.
fullText:
Through the 2024-25 season, the Los Angeles Lakers have had a total of 506 players suit up for them, going back to their days in Minneapolis. Some were forgettable, some were serviceable, some were good and a select few were flat-out legendary.

During the Lakers' 80th season of existence (they were founded back in 1946 as the Detroit Gems in the National Basketball League), LeBron Wire is taking a look at each player who has worn their jersey, whether it has been a purple and gold one or the ones they donned back in the Midwest during their early years.

Jeremy Lin took the NBA world by storm midway through the 2011-12 season when he moved into the New York Knicks' starting lineup and put together an extended stretch of big-scoring games. He had gone undrafted in 2010 out of Harvard University, not exactly a high-level basketball school, and was a seemingly invisible rookie with the Golden State Warriors, but he seemingly shot himself out of a cannon with New York.

It sparked a phenomenon people referred to as "Linsanity," and even after the rest of the league adjusted to him and his production regressed to a more consistent mean, a sizable amount of the hype surrounding him remained.

In the summer of 2014, the rebuilding Lakers acquired Lin in a trade with the Houston Rockets. By now, he was straddling the line between a low-tier starting point guard and a very solid reserve point guard. He played one season with the Lakers and started in 30 of 74 games while averaging 11.2 points and 4.6 assists in 25.8 minutes a game.

He left L.A. following that season and would have short stints with the Charlotte Hornets, Brooklyn Nets, Atlanta Hawks and Toronto Raptors before his NBA career ended. He finished with league career averages of 11.6 points on 43.3% field-goal shooting and 4.3 assists in 25.5 minutes a game.

This article originally appeared on LeBron Wire: Lakers jersey history No. 17 ‚Äî Jeremy Lin

title: Spurs could get Victor Wembanyama back for Emirates NBA Cup semifinal game vs. Thunder this weekend
description: The San Antonio Spurs are headed to the Emirates NBA Cup semifinals after defeating the Los Angeles Lakers, 132-119, on Wednesday, and might have Victor Wembanyama back in the lineup for the big tournament matchup.
fullText:
The San Antonio Spurs are headed to the Emirates NBA Cup semifinals after defeating the Los Angeles Lakers, 132-119, on Wednesday, and might have Victor Wembanyama back in the lineup for the big tournament matchup. Following the team‚Äôs quarterfinal victory over the Lakers on Wednesday, Spurs head coach Mitch Johnson to reporters that Wemby might be ready to make his return from injury over the weekend.

‚ÄúVery much so,‚Äù coach Johnson said. ‚ÄúHe had a really good day today. He had a very intense day this morning, and we‚Äôll have to see how he responds or reacts (Thursday).‚Äù

Wemby went through an intense workout on Wednesday morning and then worked out again during pregame warmups before the Lakers game. He was able to get through that workout without any extra protection on his strained calf, according to Johnson.

Wembanyama has been sidelined with his calf strain and hasn‚Äôt played since Nov. 16. However, the Spurs have been able to get through this stretch and post a 9-3 record without their All-Star big man and defensive anchor. Wemby‚Äôs potential return couldn‚Äôt come at a better time as the Spurs will face the defending NBA Champion Oklahoma City Thunder in the NBA Cup semifinals in Las Vegas on Saturday.

In Wembanyama's absence, other players like last season's Rookie of the Year Stephon Castle have had to step up even more to help carry the load. In Wednesday's win over the Lakers, Castle scored 30 points, grabbed 10 rebounds, and dished 6 assists. De'Aaron Fox chipped in with 20 points, and Keldon Johnson scored 17 off the bench.

‚ÄúI think Victor would tell you we have a deep team, and we rely upon playing together as a team,‚Äù Johnson said. ‚ÄúHe may be the biggest puzzle piece, but he needs everybody else to complete the puzzle.‚Äù

Although Wemby has missed half of San Antonio‚Äôs 24 games this season, the Spurs are 17-7 overall and currently fifth in the Western Conference. When Wembanyama is on the court, he‚Äôs been as dominant as ever this season, averaging career-highs of 26.2 points and 12.9 rebounds per game, along with 3.6 blocks.

San Antonio and OKC square off in the Emirates NBA Cup semifinals on Saturday, Dec. 13, in Las Vegas, Nevada. The NBA Cup championship game will be played on Dec. 16 in Las Vegas.

title: 40-year-old LeBron James turns back the clock with poster dunk for Lakers vs. Spurs
description: Look out below.
fullText:
40-year-old LeBron James turns back the clock with poster dunk for Lakers vs. Spurs originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

LeBron James may not be as good as he once was, but he's as good once as he ever was.

Those Toby Keith lyrics, repurposed for this moment, certainly fit what the Los Angeles Lakers' 40-year-old superstar did on Wednesday night.

With an open trip down the lane, James gathered speed like the freight train of old.

He didn't appear bothered one bit by the presence of the gigantic Luke Kornet waiting at the rim for the San Antonio Spurs.

James, who turns 41 in three weeks, rose up and thundered down a poster dunk, no questions asked.

40-YEAR OLD LEBRON POSTER ON 7'1 LUKE KORNET ü§Øüî•

UNREAL. pic.twitter.com/ekPdfMwjsR

‚Äî Bleacher Report (@BleacherReport) December 11, 2025

Maybe his streak of double-digit points is over.

Maybe he's not the first option on his team anymore.

But this is still LeBron James. And he's still got it.

What other 40-year-old in the history of the planet is doing that? None. Zero. Zilch. Nada.

That's King behavior right there.

It was the NBA Cup quarterfinals, and James wasn't holding back. The Lakers went to halftime with a deficit, but they also went to the half with this highlight.

And even in a career full of moments like this, watching LeBron do that at this stage is still remarkable.

title: Lakers fall to Spurs and are eliminated from NBA Cup contention
description: The Lakers trailed by as much as 24 points in the fourth quarter while losing to the Spurs in an NBA Cup quarterfinal game.
fullText:
Any chance the Lakers had at trying to capture a second NBA Cup championship in the third season of the tournament evaporated for good in the fourth quarter against a young, fast and athletic San Antonio Spurs team missing its best player.

The Lakers won the inaugural NBA Cup title in 2023 and had designs on winning it again in 2025 and the $500,000 cash that goes to each player on the championship team.

But it was not to be ‚Äî not with the Lakers unable to slow down the Spurs during a 132-119 quarterfinal loss Wednesday night at Crypto.com Arena.

The Lakers got down by as much as 24 points in the fourth and made a run to get to within eight points late in the fourth quarter.

But the Lakers got no closer and now will face the Suns in Phoenix on Sunday.

The Spurs will meet the defending NBA champion Oklahoma City Thunder on Saturday night in Las Vegas in the semifinals.

Luka Doncic had 35 points, eight rebounds and five assists, Marcus Smart came off the bench to score 26 and LeBron James had 19 points, 15 rebounds and eight assists. But that wasn‚Äôt enough against a Spurs team that had seven players score in double figures.

Stephon Castle led the Spurs with 30 points and De‚ÄôAaron Fox had 20.

When the Lakers needed someone to lift them when they got down by 18 points in the second, someone to provide them a spark when there wasn‚Äôt one for so much of the quarter, they finally got it from the oldest player on the court, 40-year-old LeBron James.

James drove down the lane and threw down a thunderous dunk over Spurs 7-1 center Luke Kornet, bringing the Lakers to within eight points and charging up the crowd in the process.

James growled and yelled in the face of the reeling Kornet. The crowd stood and cheered, now happy that there was a Lakers‚Äô awakening.

But the Lakers couldn‚Äôt hold on to that momentum, falling behind 70-58 at the half.

And then when the third quarter started, the Lakers came out flat, giving up back-to-back threes and two more easy baskets for the Spurs to fall into an 80-60 hole early in the third.

The Lakers didn‚Äôt make it easy on themselves either.

Doncic got a technical foul in the first quarter after no foul was called after Kelly Olynyk smacked him in the face and Lakers coach JJ Redick was called for a technical foul in the second quarter.

When the Lakers last faced the Spurs a little over a month ago here, San Antonio superstar Victor Wembanyama played in a game L.A. won, but speedy point guard De‚ÄôAaron Fox did not.

It was the opposite this time, with Fox playing and Wembanyama out with a left calf strain.

The 7-5 Wembanyama has been out for almost a month and the super-quick Fox has been back during that time, which has changed the dynamic of the Spurs, which meant the Lakers had to shift how they played defense against San Antonio.

The Spurs are more guard-oriented with Fox, Castle and Dylan Harper.

The Lakers got a taste of how much faster the Spurs are now in the first quarter, when L.A. gave up 39 points and trailed by nine after the first frame.

The Spurs show 56% from the field in the first, 50% (six-for-12) from three-point range.

Keldon Johnson came off the bench to score 13 points in the first quarter for the Spurs.

"Yeah, they're running a lot of pick and rolls with Fox, a lot of pick and rolls with Castle and Harper,‚Äù Lakers coach JJ Redick said pregame about the Spurs‚Äô new way of playing. ‚ÄúAnd all those pick and rolls lead to drives, those pick and rolls lead to kick-outs and catch two threes and then more drives. So, we've got to do a good job of containing the basketball and do a good job of contesting."

This story originally appeared in Los Angeles Times.
